ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: Overall a very good class that gave a great overview of all the physical sciences. I feel like I gained a lot out of the class, but sometimes I feel like I understand the details without having as clear of an understanding of the overall big picture. Perhaps it would be helpful to make this connection to the students and make it more clear what these calculations we are going through represent in the larger picture.

Q2 - The class was filled with people who had little to no background knowledge, and yet Prof. Anisfeld would fly past many subjects. I attribute this to the excessive quantity of material; if he had not sought to teach so much in one semester, he could have actually taught us something. As it was, many of us learned far less than we could have. The fact that more than 50% of students consistently answered the in-class questions incorrectly should have given him more pause than it did.Prof. Anisfeld is a good person who is trying very hard, but he should either change the proposed scope of this class to one that is more academic and less applied, or strongly reconsider the quantity of material.Q9b, c - The field trip with Tom Sicama was excellent; he was extremely clear, made the material fun and engaging, and was generally knowledgeable about the forest.
Question 10: The concepts are very valuable and should be understood by anyone wishing to do policy work that affects ecology.

I thought this course was really hard and attempted to cover a lot of material. I thought it was too much for someone without any college level physical science classes, and with no intention of being an expert in this area! I thought it required us to understand things in a lot of detail, which I found really challenging.

Q 2-4: I felt that the instructor did not provide sufficient explanations of many of the concepts that were addressed in this course. As a "foundation" course, there was an expectation that I could take it without prior background and still succeed. My experience was that this course was unrealistically challenging and unrealistically time consuming. It was a common occurrence that a given set of material would be covered in class, and then a different set of material or skills, which had not been covered, would be required for homework. This made completion of the homework by myself impossible on nearly every occasion. I attended an average of two multi-hour help sessions every single week, and still failed to grasp much of the material.To challenge a student is to ask them to take a set of skills, and to apply them in ways that push their conceptual boundaries, thereby forming new connections, novel findings, and intellectual growth. The out-of-class assignments were not challenging, since they required leaps that were too great for the majority of students. They were instead, just "hard". It was a common occurrence to have 15+/- students at each help session, out of a class of 21+/-. I feel that this reflects an unrealistic expectation of student time and energy, and of pedagogy. At the very least, the professor needs to be upfront with students about what will be required of them to complete the course with moderate success.The difficulty of this course is a reflection of both the material and somewhat unsuccessful pedagogical practice. Shimi is a devoted educator - he provides his students with copious time and energy, is always prepared, and was successful in covering the broad reach of "physical sciences". He is one of the more devoted educators that I had this term. But, he was not open to constructive criticism of his educational methods. As an educator myself, I would argue that it is imperative that one be receptive methodological changes.An educator seeks to impart knowledge and skills and to foster growth in the student; the student seeks to take in and build knowledge and skills. When a student who is actively engaged and is putting in significant time and energy fails to acquired the knowledge and skills needed to complete their studies, it is a reflection of how the information is delivered. We must ask ourselves about the quality of education - whether a cursory overview of many topics is better than in-depth training in fewer areas. When an engaged student fails to grasp the material, both the educator and the student are failing to get what they want. I was disappointed that when I addressed the professor about this issue, I was instructed to drop-out of the course if I was not able to keep up or complete the assignments. I encourage careful reflection on the course structure and the relative number of students that need large amounts of outside help to complete assignments. I do not intend to target this course for negative criticism, but feel that this form of honest critique is essential for building a more successful course and more successful pedagogy.

i am responding to questions 2 and 6.this class was taught too quickly and the material was not taught with enough focus on the concepts and their applications. prof. anisfeld tried to get through far too much material. the class felt extremely haphazard, and i and many of my peers didn't know what the point of much of what we were learning was. the readings helped somewhat, but they were often tangential, and it was difficult to triangulate an understanding of how it all came together. this class is certainly not suitable for somebody who has little or no experience with science, and asking such people to take this class is a waste of their short time here. for those of us who have some experience with science and are looking to get a sense for the physical science underlying environmental questions, a much more concept-based, applied class might be more helpful. the hard science is useful, i suppose, but i can guarantee you that most of us are not coming away remembering any of it. just not what most of us are here for.

Question 10: I am an MF candidate and though I enjoyed all the topics covered during the semester, some were more relevant to my particular focus than others. This is a broad course that covers many topics and I think that should be made clear to MFs.

I took this course with some background in environmental science, assuming that I would learn more about how science was used in "environmental management." But mostly, it was like a high school science class, more about memorizing when the glaciers formed and less about how we could use this info in future applications. For me, that meant a lot of the material was repetitive and the class was not useful. At the very least, the final should have been a take-home in which we actually could reference what we learned in class and apply it to solve real solutions. Instead, it was exactly like the midterm we had had a few weeks earlier.

In general, I really enjoyed the course. My only suggestion would be to streamline the information that is provided. Given the large amount of information covered in the course it might be better absorbed if some of the most extraneous info were cut out. For example, you could spend a little less time on Connecticut geologic history in order to spend more time on later subjects. I thought that the time allotted to soils and water was appropriate, but insufficient time was allowed for the atmosphere and oceans.
The Tarbuck reading is very helpful. Additionally the office hours were a must. I greatly appreciate how much Shimi made himself available to us.
A shotgun introduction to a lot of terms. You won't necessarily retain anything about them, but at least the next time you hear them you won't start from complete zero.
It was cutting edge and mixed the conceptual with the pragmatic.
I liked how things were linked to environmental problems, which made it easier to understand how these principles and concepts were relevant to policymakers.

The instructor's devotion to his students was the best part of this course. Teaching was clearly a priority for him, and it was nice to get active participation in this regard. Shimi was responsive to emails, conducted regular office hours, and provided sufficient amounts of out-of-class help hours.
I know it will be useful in the future.
the review sessions in which many of us actually did the problem sets. prof. anisfelds handouts.
Learning about wind movement, ocean currents, coastal ecosystems and pollutant movement.
Excellent TAs and Shimi's ability to teach patiently. Remarkable.
Good overview of basic science concepts you may have missed in high school/college. Interactive question/answer slides in lecture.
Shimi is a great teacher and offers very thorough explanations.

Shimi does his best to give us a full overview of the physical sciences. He has to move quickly in order to cover everything but his pace is good. He and the TAs are readily available to help with problem sets and they are extremely dedicated to teaching and helping you understand the material.
Shimi is the best professor I've had at F&ES. He is extremely hard working and clearly cares that students learn the material.
Climate and energy change section.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: Not much - just (as stated above) making sure that we understand the greater implications of the more detailed calculations and equations we are learning.

The only way to complete the problem sets in a reasonable amount of time and without outside help was to attend the "review sessions." In these sessions, students sat around making mistakes until the TAs came over to walk them through the next step. Many students joked that these sessions were "putting the time in," but this puts the students who are unable to attend the sessions because of other engagements at an extreme disadvantage. If your problem sets are so hard that students have to be spoon-fed the answers by the TAs, then you should probably modify their difficulty.Note: this is not in any way a critique of the TAs; they are not paid to teach the students the material, which is what would have had to happen at the sessions in order to avoid the spoon-feeding that instead took place.
In-class lectures should also include more mathematical examples, so that it is easier for us to prepare for the problem sets.
The organization of the class.

This class is trying to take on too much material. I think either the focus should be to essentially cover Tarbuck and those more qualitative components of physical sciences, or else just focus more intensely on say air and water as "case studies". We could become scientifically literate in a more complete fashion.

There was so much material, and some of it seemed quite disjointed. For example, a lot of the stuff on the problem sets was not covered in lectures, classnotes, or reading materials. It was hard (if not impossible) to be able to independently bring oneself up to speed on concepts without help from the professor or TAs.
See question 11 - pace and delivery.

The text readings were only somewhat helpful. The Tarbuck text was pretty clear and straightforward, but the topics that were covered were the easier ones in the course that didn't require that much review. It would be helpful to have a text that adequately explained the more difficult concepts so that we could supplement our learning on our own.

the pacing and the lack of conceptual connections made. extremely fast and haphazard and not really in tune with what would suit most people who take this class. i do not mean to say we need to be totally accommodated, but to tell us this is a requirement when most of us are really not going to apply the bulk of the qualitative material from this class ever again is totally ridiculous. perhaps there can be a more concept-based science class, in which the real questions and their applicability can be ramped up and the quantitative can be tuned down a bit.
The rapid pace of the course made it difficult for me to retain all the information bombarding students.

The lectures bounced between easy and hard, and it was clear that many students hadn't really grasped main concepts before the professor moved on. Shimi is very patient, but sometimes he has difficulty distilling major concepts down into teachable chunks. (For example, early on, someone asked a question about significant figures for which the answer was basically, "follow rules of basic mathematical rounding," but instead Shimi went through a bunch of examples.)Finally, many students just went to office hours and were basically fed the answers to problem sets, disadvantaging students who couldn't attend.

The course could be a little more focused. I think that it would be beneficial to spend less time on basic chemistry and more time on general concepts such as interactions between the various Earth spheres.
Sometimes I thought Shimi could do a better job tying the material back to management and management decisions but overall it was a very well taught course.

The course is too theoretical and has little applicability to actual management. I also felt that too many different and often unrelated topics were covered. This made the course feel episodic and learning the material difficult. I believe the concept of the class is fundamentally flawed.
The course should not cover so much material. At the end, it comes down to quality vs. quantity.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: I went to the instructor's office hours every week. I found them incredibly helpful.
See Q13 response.
All three TAs (especially Reade) and the professor were all very helpful.
They were extremely helpful.
The TA was always responsive and thorough.
Very available and patient.

The availability was very good. Quality was also good, but I felt like my lack of understanding was so huge that the time I was able to spend with the TAs and the professor (limited by other class commitments) was inadequate to comprehend the material to the degree that I would have liked.

Excellent. Both the instructor and the TAs were regularly available, offered a large number of out-of-class help hours, and responded to emails. They were all committed, and provided the human resources that ultimately allowed me to succeed in this course.

Shimi is very helpful in office hours, definitely better than the TAs. I really get the sense that he cares about being hands-on in the learning process. The number of office hours sessions was appropriate.
extremely high and satisfactory.
The TA's were mostly helpful and always available within their alloted time frames.
Excellent.
See above.
great!

See my response to Question 12. Both Shimi and the TAs made themselves available more so than any of my other classes. Shimi's help and patience during office hour's for problem sets and review sessions was very much appreciated. Wish my other professors demonstrated a similar commitment to teaching at FES.
Shimi and the TAs were very available. I applaud their efforts.
Great!

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I took this course mainly because I don't have much background in the physical sciences. I have an undergrad background in ecology, but have not had as much exposure to this side of the natural sciences.
It was good because it reinforced a lot of things I had learned in undergrad when I studied biology. It connected those concepts to management applications, which was novel for me.

I felt physical science was a deficiency in my education, so I thought I'd try to address this by taking this class. I thought it'd be helpful to be able to occasionally wear this hat when approaching environmental problems (from a policy or advocacy perspective), or at least to be able to understand what my colleagues are talking about!
This course was taken to round out my prior background and experience. It was not part of my target field/areas of inquiry.
I have had some science courses, but I would like to continue to build my background. That is why I took this course. I plan to try to take at least one other science course while at FES.
i am not taking away any of the quant stuff. only the concepts, which i basically taught myself because prof. anisfeld barely had time to teach the quant stuff.

It gives people with non scientific background a good idea of how pollutants move through water, soil and air, a more in depth understanding of what causes climate change and an idea of the complexity of measuring precise amounts of energy, radiation, concentration, acidity and alkalinity.
I should have just taken a class in a discipline I was interested in, instead of this overview.
This is probably the only physical science course I will take at FES and I wanted a general overview of the subject matter and this course did just that.
As an MF, I had hoped to learn skills applicable to land management. I found that this was not the case.
Most of the content does not really relates especially sections in soils and water.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I took this course because I want to feel like I have a good understanding of all the natural sciences relevant to environmental management.

I took this course because I wanted to learn Physical Sciences for Environmental Managers. I expected to learn a bit about the different sciences, what real world effect they have, and how ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGERS should use the knowledge to apply to real world situations. Instead I received a crash course in physical sciences for those seeking to be professors of physical science.Perhaps a change of name might help to better manage expectations?
Refresher in chemistry and math.
I wanted to gain broader understanding about the cycle of pollutants in the environment and forces/patterns affecting the change of their concentrations.
Because on the syllabus it had listed that they would teach paleobiogeography and evolutionary concepts--a broad scope.
Same as Q15 (see above).

I took this course to ground me basic physical sciences to which I had not previously been exposed. It was to "fill in the blanks", so to speak, and help provide greater clarity on some fundamental concepts of environmental science.
I wanted to foundational science course, and to be able to take other science classes in the future.
to gain a better understanding of the scientific processes that underlie environmental topics. to be able to interrelate these processes.
Because I did not have the choice to take science courses in my undergraduate degree.
Because I felt I needed to increase my exposure to physical sciences.
Wanted an overview of physical science FOR ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGERS.
See response to Question 16.
As I want to take a few climate change courses in my second year.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes it did. I feel like I have a very solid background in the physical sciences now.
I think the exposure is helpful, but I'm disappointed that I wasn't able to more fully grasp the content presented in the class.

Yes and no. See question 11.This course did live up to my expectations in providing me with a broad overview of many aspects of the physical world with which I did not have prior experience. I formed many connections between facets of my background in environmental sciences, and am thankful for this.
Yes.
yes, despite the work in pursuit of unnecessary material i had to put in.
Yes.
Yes, for the most part.
No; see answers above.

For the most part, yes. I thought that sometimes we got into too much detail but maybe that is whats necessary to really understand the material. Wish we spent a little more on geology but overall it met my expectations.

The course did not live up to my expectations. I would suggest that students take a course on hydrology, geology, or environmental chemistry, rather than this class, which tries to combine the there three.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: I came out of the exam feeling as though I would retain very little of what I had learned. The slides are also lacking in description and application of concepts, so that going back to them for future reference will only serve to confuse me. Google will be a better source.
Yes, my understanding of the environmental factors/forces has improve a lot.
Same as Q17, see above.
Yes. In terms of "filling in the blanks" of my prior education, this course provided just what I expected.
Overall I thought the first class did accurately lay out what the topics would be. I definitely gained competency on new topics.
no. still pretty confused about a lot of the connections. this effective teaching of this class is too ambitious a project for a single semester.

Yes and no. I would have liked to be asked more about the theoretical aspects of the material we were viewing instead of a more problem solving oriented evaluation. As most of us taking the class have no strong scientific background and do not intend to pursue scientific research, I think it would have been more useful to orient the tests towards a conceptual understanding as opposed to a mathematical focus.
a tad too broad.
No, see answers above.
I am very happy with the course; however, it would be great if there were a similar course that followed up on this one but which delved deeper into these concepts.
I did not. I was looking for practical skills and didn't feel that I learned many.
Yes, a general and vague understanding of environmental chemistry.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I did not participate in a formal work group, but I always (read, had to) work with other students and attend the out-of-class help sessions every week. These were absolutely essential,as I was entirely unable to complete the assignments on my own.
it was a very miniscule portion of the class. it helped us get our work done on time.
They made the problem sets possible.
There wasnt any official group work or group projects but Shimi let us work on problem sets together and given their difficulty this was appreciated and helpful.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Attend problem set sessions for all problem sets!

If you are an MEM wanting some exposure to physical sciences that you can actually use in your career, take another course. If you like physical sciences and have already taken coursework in this, then you will be unimpressed and maybe even confused. The only students I would point towards this course are those who are interesting in pursuing an academic career in physical sciences but have so far had no academic exposure.
Sometimes the work seems mundane but the concepts on how dynamic ecosystems are are invaluable.
Study really hard for the exams.

I would suggest they think hard about whether/how this would fit into their career goals before taking it... because it's a hard class. I would suggest they identify all their (even most basic) questions on a weekly basis, and ask them in office hours.

1) Be prepared for 20+/- hours of coursework a week.2) Be prepared for attend two 2.5 hour long out-of-class help sessions each week to complete the assignments.3) Start studying for the exams early.4) If many students are struggling, collectively address this with the professor. This is your education, and if it isn't working for you, do something about it.5) Do the reading before the classes that will cover that material, so you have some basic familiarity of concepts before they are gone through in class.6) This course has many formula and numerical concepts - be prepared if you are not a "math person"

I would tell them to prepare to put in about 8 hours a week on the problem sets. If they have other courses that have problem sets or other time-consuming assignments, it may be difficult to take the classes together. Also, be prepared to cover several topics quickly - this is more of a survey course, and it can be difficult to switch quickly between topics. Shimi is definitely a MUCH better science teacher than most, as far as his ability to explain topics and his care for students.
really, really make sure you want to take this class for its own sake. if you take it to inform your other work here, you'll waste your time. it will behelpful, but not in some essential kind of way.
Use the TA sessions for questions class material in addition to problem set review.
If you've never had real science classes, read the textbook before class. If you have had real science classes, skip this class and take an actual course in the discipline you are interested in.

I would take this course if you feel like you're lacking in environmental chemistry or in the physical sciences in general. Look at the syllabus and if you feel like you've learned most of the material in the past dont bother taking this course. With that said, Shimi is a great teacher and you do learn a lot. The material is a bit intimidating if you are not strong in math and chemistry but in hindsight I'm glad I took it.
Take advantage of the office hours. They are the best way to learn the material if it doesn't make sense during lecture.
Chemistry college class should be a pre-requisite.
